Title:
Phylogeny and evolution of body size in didelphid marsupials
(Marsupialia: Didelphimorphia: Didelphidae)
Keywords:
Didelphidae, body size, phylogeny, character mapping,
phyletic giantism, nanism
Abstract:
Most extant New World marsupials belong in Didelphidae,
which comprises c. 110 currently recognized species of opossums.
Didelphids are small mammals with the mean of species body size ranging
from c. 7 g to 2.2 kg. The largest species belong in a single clade,
while substantial variation remains scattered across the remainder of
groups. We seek out to explore the details of this size variation in an
evolutionary framework. To this end, we first reconstructed the
phylogeny of didelphids based on an extensive sample of sequences from
10 genes. We recovered a fully resolved, extraordinarily robust
phylogeny that tested and confirmed most previously reported groupings,
providing a simultaneous depiction of phylogenetic relationships for 81%
of currently recognized species and all relevant supra-specific clades.
As much as 69% of total size variation in didelphids was explained by
this tree. Mapped on it, size variation evolved as much as 6.7 kg of
changes, starting from a reconstructed ancestral body mass range of
22-33 g. No single, family-wide pattern was evident; in fact, the
dominant pattern for size variation was that of increases in body mass
along a few successive branches, or phyletic giantism, followed by
apomorphic nanism (decreases localized in single branches). Phyletic
trends indicated the persistence of gradual, directional changes along
considerable spans of geological time. We conclude that evolutionary
size variation of substantial interest may reside in groups of small
mammals, which should be explored further in more groups in the light of
robust phylogenetic reconstructions as in didelphid marsupials.
